start.title:
Engineering the Depths

Mastering Circle Geometry for Norway's Floating Tunnel
start.description: Can you help Dr. Larsen design a groundbreaking floating tunnel beneath Bjørnafjorden? In this STEAMQuest, you'll apply circle theorems, tangents, and inscribed angles to ensure structural stability, safe clearances, and optimal lighting—bringing this ambitious engineering project to life!

S2_D1_F3_C0.heading: Welcome to Bjørnafjorden
S2_D1_F3_C0.body: The deep waters of Norway's Bjørnafjorden stretch across the landscape, connecting distant towns but creating a major transportation challenge. Standing atop Liafjellet Mountain, Dr. Larsen, and Astrid overlook the fjord, where ferries slowly make their crossings. Below the surface, powerful currents flow, shaping the ambitious idea of a floating tunnel—a structure that could revolutionize travel in Norway.

S3.S3_D1_F4_C3: Five kilometers of open water—forcing every vehicle to either wait for ferries or take a long detour. This is costing our economies millions!
S3.S3_D2_F5_C1: Well we wanted to build a bridge, but Dr. Larsen told me it is not possible.
S3.S3_D3_F6_C2: It is like Astrid says, any bridge would need support pillars in 2,950 feet of water—that's way too deep I'm afraid.
S3.S3_D4_F7_C3: So why no tunnel then?
S3.S3_D5_F8_C1: A traditional tunnel would have to go even deeper to avoid the fjord bottom. The access roads alone would add kilometers to the journey.
S3.S3_D6_F9_C3: Okay, so no bridge, no regular tunnel… seems like we are out of luck.
S3.S3_D7_F10_C2: Well, we could consider a floating tunnel. Suspended just below the surface, anchored by cables to floating pontoons. No deep drilling, no massive pillars—just precise engineering. Look at the tablet!

S4_D0_F11_C9.title: Underwater Tunnel
S4_D0_F11_C9.alt: Illustration of an underwater tunnel suspended beneath the surface, supported by floating pontoons, with a ship passing above.
S4_D0_F11_C9.longDescription: The illustration shows a submerged tunnel system suspended underwater, supported by large circular pontoons floating on the surface. The tunnel has two parallel cylindrical tubes designed for vehicle traffic. In the background, a ship is sailing on calm waters with distant mountains visible, highlighting how the underwater tunnel allows unobstructed marine navigation above.

S4.S4_D1_F11_C3: Underwater? Will it be stable? What about maintenance costs?
S4.S4_D2_F12_C1: And what about the water pressure at that depth? The currents, the structural forces…

S5.S5_D1_F13_C2: To keep the tunnel in place, we'll attach support cables from the floating pontoons above. These cables must be the right length to maintain stability and prevent movement caused by currents.
S5.S5_D2_F14_C3: We can't have it too close to the surface if ships are passing through.
S5.S5_D3_F15_C2: Exactly. We need at least 66 feet of clearance to allow large ships to sail safely above the tunnel and avoid collisions.
S5.S5_D4_F16_C1: So, we know the tunnel needs to stay deep enough for ships to pass. But how do we decide exactly where to place it? We can't just guess.
S5.S5_D5_F17_C2: Let's assume the tunnel has a diameter of 38 feet. If we place the tunnel so that the top sits 66 feet below the surface, that puts the center of the tunnel at 85 feet deep.
S5.S5_D6_F18_C1: Okay, so we know the depth to the center and the tunnel's size. But how do we figure out the cable length?

S6_D0_F19_C9.title: Calculating Cable Lengths

about.heading: Calculating Cable Lengths
about.body:
• Tangent Property: The support cables act as tangents to the tunnel, which means they are perpendicular to the tunnel’s radius at the point of contact
  • Pythagorean Theorem: In a right triangle, the square of the length of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the lengths of the other two sides
    a² +  b² =  c²

    where:

    • c = Hypotenuse (longest side)
    • a, b = Other sides of the right triangle

help.heading: How to Use
help.body:
• Use the slider to adjust the tunnel's depth. Observe how the cable length changes as the depth increases or decreases
  • Ensure that the tunnel depth allows ships to pass above the tunnel without collision
  • Click the "See Calculation for Cable Length" button to view the step-by-step Pythagorean theorem calculation

S6_D0_F19_C9.ariaLabel: A diagram showing an underwater tunnel (dark circle) suspended beneath the water's surface by yellow cables extending from a pontoon platform above.
S6_D0_F19_C9.pythagoreanTheoremAriaLabel: A squared plus B squared equals C squared
S6_D0_F19_C9.step1Title: Step 1: Rearrange to solve for cable length
S6_D0_F19_C9.step1FormulaAriaLabel: B squared equals C squared minus A squared
S6_D0_F19_C9.step2Formula1AriaLabel: B squared equals C squared minus A squared
S6_D0_F19_C9.step2Formula2AriaLabel: B squared equals vertical depth in feet squared minus tunnel radius in feet squared
S6_D0_F19_C9.step2Formula3AriaLabel: B squared equals vertical depth squared in square feet minus tunnel radius squared in square feet
S6_D0_F19_C9.step2Formula4AriaLabel: B squared equals cable length squared in square feet
S6_D0_F19_C9.step3Formula1AriaLabel: B equals square root of cable length squared in square feet
S6_D0_F19_C9.step3Formula2AriaLabel: B equals cable length in feet

S6.S6_D1_F19_C2: Let's look back at the tablet, look how the cable connects to the tunnel—they're tangent to the tunnel.
S6.S6_D2_F20_C1: Right! And I remember that a tangent to a circle is always perpendicular to the radius at the point of contact.
S6.S6_D3_F21_C2: Exactly, that forms a right triangle.
S6.S6_D4_F22_C1: That means we can use the Pythagorean theorem to find the cable length!
S6.S6_D5_F23_C2: Now that you understand the concept, let's put it to the test. What should be the minimum cable length needed to keep the tunnel stable if its center is 85 feet below the surface?
S6.S6_D6_F24_C1: So if we apply the Pythagorean theorem, we get 82.6 feet as the minimum cable length. That ensures the tunnel stays secure while maintaining proper depth for ships to pass!

S7.S7_D1_F25_C2: Now that we've determined the correct cable length to hold the tunnel at the right depth, there's another challenge we need to address.
S7.S7_D3_F27_C2: Keeping the tunnel at the correct depth is one thing, but keeping it stable is another. Water currents could push the tunnel from side to side, causing it to oscillate.
S7.S7_D4_F28_C3: Like a pendulum? That could be dangerous!

S8_D0_F30_C9.title: Calculating Anchor Angle

about.heading: Calculating Cable Length
about.body:
• Secant-Tangent Angle Theorem: The angle formed outside a circle by two secants, tangents, or one of each is equal to half the difference of the intercepted arcs
  • Mathematical Approach:
    • Identify the intercepted arcs:
      • γ (gamma): The larger intercepted arc
      • β (beta): The smaller intercepted arc
    • Compute the external angle α using the formula:
      α   =  12  (γ  -  β)

help.heading: How to Use
help.body:
• Adjust the tunnel depth slider to change the depth of the structure
  • Observe how α gets smaller, when the depth decreases because, γ shrinks and β expands

S8_D0_F30_C9.ariaLabel: A diagram showing an underwater tunnel (dark circle) suspended beneath the water by yellow cables in a cross pattern extending from a pontoon platform above.

S8.S8_D16_F30_C2: Exactly. If the tunnel sways too much, it could cause structural stress and make driving inside unsafe. That's why we need to add crossed support lines to keep it in position, like this!
S8.S8_D1_F30_C1: Alright, we can install vertical support cables that hang perpendicular to the pontoons and tangent to the tunnel.
S8.S8_D2_F31_C2: Yes, those provide the primary stability for maintaining depth.
S8.S8_D2_FX1_C1: Now we also add crossed support lines to stop the tunnel from swaying. But how do we know exactly where to place them?
S8.S8_D2_FX2_C2: Good question. The cables should attach at precise angles to ensure maximum stability, and we keep all the cables tangent to the tunnel!
S8.S8_D3_F32_C1: So the goal is to find the right anchor angles where the cables connect to the pontoons, right?
S8.S8_D4_F33_C2: Exactly! And just like before, geometry helps us solve this. The key here is understanding how the angles inside the tunnel shift as the depth changes.
S8.S8_D5_F34_C2: Now, to determine the correct anchor angles, we need to use a geometric property about angles formed outside a circle. Take a look at the angles inside the tunnel.
S8.S8_D6_F35_C1: I see three labels — γ (gamma), β (beta), and α (alpha). What do they represent?
S8.S8_D7_F36_C2:
Good observation. Here's how they work:
  • γ (gamma) is the larger intercepted arc.
  • β (beta) is the smaller intercepted arc.
  • α (alpha) is the anchor angle—the one we need to calculate for the support cables.
S8.S8_D8_F37_C1: So as the tunnel moves deeper, γ and β change, which means α changes too?
S8.S8_D9_F38_C2:
You're absolutely right! That brings us to the theorem:
The measure of an angle formed by two lines that intersect outside a circle is half the difference of the measures of the intercepted arcs.
S8.S8_D10_F39_C1: So that means, α = ½ ( γ − β )
S8.S8_D11_F40_C3: This is amazing, I don't usually follow the math, but if this works it'll save countless people from long waits!
S8.S8_D12_F41_C1: Alright! What's our scenario?
S8.S8_D13_F42_C2: Let's say the tunnel's depth is confirmed at 102 feet. Based on this depth, what should be the anchor angle for the cross cables?
S8.S8_D14_F43_C1: We get 22.1 degrees as the correct anchor angle!
S8.S8_D15_F44_C2: That's right! At 102 feet depth, the cables should be anchored at 22.1 degrees to ensure the tunnel stays stable and resists swinging like a pendulum.

S9.S9_D1_F45_C3: We have stabilized the tunnel, but we also have to make sure that it adheres to regulations. What if there is a fire? I think safety is key, and we should have sidewalks of at least 6 feet for people to be able to escape.
S9.S9_D2_F46_C1: I hadn't thought of that! Dr. Larsen, can we make sure of that too?

about.heading: Calculating Tunnel Diameter
about.body:
• Thale's Theorem: A triangle inscribed in a semicircle has a right angle at the circumference
    • If D and P are endpoints of a diameter, and C is any point on the circle, then: ∠DCP=90°
  • Chord Length Product Theorem: The product of the segment lengths of two intersecting chords is constant
    • If two chords EF and CP intersect at point B, then: (EB × BF) = (CB × BP)
  • Pythagorean Theorem: In a right triangle, the sum of the squares of the two legs equals the square of the hypotenuse

help.heading: Need Help?
help.body:
• Follow the steps to apply Thales’ Theorem and Chord Length Product Theorem to find missing values
  • Fill in the Missing Angle First
    • A right triangle always includes one angle measuring 90°
    • The angle opposite the diameter is 90° when the diameter is the hypotenuse
  • Solve for the Unknown Segment Using the Chord Length Product Theorem
    • Drag and drop the correct segment values into the equation
    • Ensure you select the two intersecting chord segments when filling the blanks

slide1.ariaLabel: A diagram of an underwater tunnel (dark circle) with white measurement lines showing rectangle ABCD, points E and F marking chords where AB (24 ft) lies on chord EF, with measurements EA and BF (6 ft each) and CB (18 ft).

slide2.ariaLabel: A diagram of an underwater tunnel (dark circle) showing rectangle ABCD with measurements AB (24 ft), CB (18 ft), EA and BF (6 ft each), plus a diagonal dashed line DP passing through center point O.

slide3.ariaLabel: A diagram of an underwater tunnel (dark circle) showing a triangle DCP with dashed white lines, where points D, C, and P are on the circle's circumference.
slide3.quePart1: If D and P are points on a circle's diameter, and C is any other point on the circle, then angle DCP is always
slide3.successMessage: Excellent! This 90-degree angle property is crucial for our underwater tunnel construction.
slide3.failureMessage1: Hint: Think about the properties of a right triangle in this context.
slide3.failureMessage2: Hint: Thales' Theorem states that an angle inscribed in a semicircle is always 90 degrees.

slide5.title: Theorem:
slide5.ariaLabel: A diagram of an underwater tunnel (dark circle) showing two intersecting chords: chord EF (30 ft total) and chord CP, which intersect at point B. Measurements shown include segments CB (18 ft), BP (labeled as “x”), and BF (6 ft).
slide5.description: For a given point and circle, the product of the lengths of the two segments from the point to the circle is constant along any line through the point and circle.
slide5.successMessage: Correct! Therefore, x = 10 ft
slide5.failureMessage: Not quite right. Try arranging the numbers differently to form a valid equation.

slide6.title: Pythagorean Theorem
slide6.ariaLabel: A diagram of an underwater tunnel (dark circle) showing right triangle DCP with dashed white lines. Measurements include DC (24 ft) and CP (28 ft).
slide6.description: In right triangle DCP, according to the Pythagorean theorem:
slide6.successMessage: Correct! Using the Pythagorean theorem: 24² + 28² = DP². Therefore, DP = 36.9 ft.
slide6.failureMessage: Not quite right. Remember, in a right triangle, the hypotenuse (DP) is the longest side and is opposite to the right angle.

S10.S10_D1_F47_C2: Of course we can! Let me draw the tunnel.
S10.S10_D2_F48_C3: Oh and trucks need to use it as well, so the tunnel must be at least 18 feet high at the roadside!
S10.S10_D3_F49_C2: I'll use a little box to show the minimum height.
S10.S10_D4_F50_C1: This makes sense. So we know that the main road, AB, needs to be 24 feet wide, plus 6 feet walkways on each side, bringing the total width to 36 feet.
S10.S10_D5_F51_C2: Great! Now, we need to determine the tunnel's diameter, DP.
S10.S10_D6_F52_C1: How do we figure that out?
S10.S10_D7_F53_C2: Thales' theorem might help. Let us zoom in on the triangle we just made.
S10.S10_D8_F54_C2: Thales' theorem tells us that if a triangle is inscribed in a semicircle, the angle opposite the diameter is always a right angle. Go ahead, fill in the missing answer for ∠DCP.
S10.S10_D9_F55_C1: Since the triangle is inscribed in a semicircle, ∠DCP must be 90 degrees! But how does that help us in finding the diameter?
S10.S10_D10_F56_C2: Well, if DCP forms a right triangle, we can use the Pythagorean theorem to solve for DP, the tunnel's diameter.
S10.S10_D11_F57_C3: Aha! Even I remember this from high school. But we do not have CP yet, or do we?
S10.S10_D12_F58_C2: Good question! We know DC is 24 feet, but to find CP, we have this theorem which tells us that if we multiply the two segment lengths of two chords, they are equal.
S10.S10_D13_F59_C1: So we can write it as EB × BF = CB × BP.
S10.S10_D14_F60_C2: Exactly! This is called the Chord Length Product Theorem. Let’s use it by filling in the missing values and solving for CP.
S10.S10_D15_F61_C1:
That gives: 30 × 6 = 18 × x. So BP is 10 feet.

CP is both those segments together, so
CP = CB + BP = 28 feet.
S10.S10_D16_F62_C2: Well done! Now that we have CP, use the Pythagorean theorem to determine the diameter DP.
S10.S10_D17_F63_C1: According to the Pythagorean theorem, DC² + CP² = DP², which gives us the tunnel's diameter, DP as 36.9 feet.
S10.S10_D18_F64_C2: Exactly! With a 36.9 feet diameter, the tunnel fits the road, sidewalks, and vehicle clearance. If the sidewalk width changes, we can use the same process to find the new diameter.

S11.S11_D1_F65_C3: It's starting to feel like a real tunnel now! But something still feels… off.
S11.S11_D2_F66_C2: What do you mean?
S11.S11_D3_F67_C3: Well, imagine driving through here. The tunnel is wide enough, but will it feel safe? Can drivers see clearly as they enter?
S11.S11_D4_F68_C2: Good observation! Visibility inside the tunnel is just as important as its structure. If drivers can't see well, it increases the risk of accidents.
S11.S11_D5_F69_C1: Well, the car's headlights seem to light up the road. Maybe that's enough for drivers to see?

about.heading: Calculating Angle of Light Spread
about.body:
• Inscribed Angle Theorem: The angle formed by two points on a circle and a point on its circumference is always half the corresponding central angle
    α  =  β2

    where:

    • α is the inscribed angle (light spread in the tunnel)
    • β is the central angle subtended by the same chord
  • Sine Formula: In a right-angled triangle, the sine of an angle is the ratio of the length of the opposite side to the length of the hypotenuse
    sin ( θ ) = oppositehypotenuse

help.heading: Need Help?
help.body:
• Understand Light Spread: The light beam forms an inscribed angle α, determining how much of the tunnel is illuminated
  • Trigonometric Calculation of Angle: The sine function is used to calculate the inscribed angle α based on known segment lengths, opposite and hypotenuse
  • Dynamic Adjustment of α: If the tunnel's diameter increases, the radius r increases, changing the central angle β, which then affects α

slide1.ariaLabel: A diagram of an underwater tunnel (dark circle) showing a car with headlights illuminating part of the tunnel interior, with a horizontal white line representing the road surface.
slide1.description: This underwater tunnel requires proper lighting to ensure safe passage for vehicles.

slide2.ariaLabel: A diagram of an underwater tunnel (dark circle) showing a car and dashed white lines forming a triangle with angle α (alpha) labeled at the apex.
slide2.svgDescription: The inscribed angle <tspan style='font-family: Besley; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic'>α</tspan> in the tunnel
slide2.description: α represents the spread of light from the street lamp, forming a chord in our underwater tunnel.

slide3.ariaLabel: A diagram of an underwater tunnel (dark circle) showing two triangles formed by dashed white lines: an outer triangle with angle α (alpha) at the apex and an inner triangle with angle β (beta) at the center.
slide3.description1: According to the Inscribed Angle Theorem: The inscribed angle (α) is always equal to half the central angle (β).
slide3.description2: Therefore: α = β2

slide4.ariaLabel: A diagram of an underwater tunnel (dark circle) showing a triangular light beam with labeled points A, C, and D. Measurements include the horizontal distance AD (18 ft), the diagonal distance AC (18.45 ft), and an angle labeled β/2 at point C.
slide4.svgDescription: Determining Angle <tspan style='font-family: Besley; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic'>α</tspan> in an Underwater Tunnel Cross-section
slide4.formula: ∠ACD = 1818.45
slide4.successMessage: Correct! sin(∠ACD) = 1818.45 gives us the angle ∠ACD.
slide4.failureMessage: Try again! Think about which trigonometric function relates the opposite and hypotenuse sides.

slide5.ariaLabel: A diagram of an underwater tunnel showing a light triangle with apex C, angles α and β, with measurements AD (18 ft) and AC (18.45 ft).
slide5.svgDescription: Determining Angle <tspan style='font-family: Besley; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic'>α</tspan> in an Underwater Tunnel Cross-section
slide5.formula1: ∠ACD = arcsin(1818.45)
slide5.formula2: ∠ACD = 77.3°

slide6.ariaLabel: A diagram of an underwater tunnel showing a car, with points P (top), C (center), A and B (road ends) connected by dashed white lines forming triangles with angle β.
slide6.description1: Line AB length: 36 ft
slide6.description2: The required illumination angle α is

S12.S12_D3_F72_C2: While headlights help, they only illuminate a short distance ahead. Without proper tunnel lighting, visibility would be poor, making driving unsafe.
S12.S12_D4_F73_C2: It would be best to create some lighting, like this! We need the lights to cover the full width of the road and both walkways, which we determined was 36 feet. The spread of light forms an inscribed angle, which determines how much of the tunnel gets illuminated.
S12.S12_D5_F74_C1: If the light forms an inscribed angle, there must be a way to relate it to the diameter. How can we use geometry to find the exact angle?
S12.S12_D6_F75_C2: This is where the Inscribed Angle Theorem will help us. It states that the light spread (α) is always half of the central angle (β) at the tunnel's center.
S12.S12_D7_F76_C1: This would only be helpful if the central angle (β) were known.
S12.S12_D8_F77_C2: That's correct! To find β, let me help you out. First, let's draw a perpendicular line CD from the center to the chord AB. Do you notice anything?
S12.S12_D9_F78_C1: I see that it splits the chord into two equal parts. If we know AC and AD, we could calculate ∠ACD, which gives us β/2 which is α.
S12.S12_D10_F79_C2: Good! Now, to find ∠ACD, we need to use trigonometry. Based on the given values, which trigonometric function should we use to set up the equation?
S12.S12_D11_F80_C1: Since we have the opposite side (18 feet) and the hypotenuse (18.45 feet), we use the sine function.
S12.S12_D12_F81_C2: Great! Now, go ahead and find ∠ACD using the formula.
S12.S12_D13_F82_C1: Alright, using the formula: ∠ACD = arcsin(18/18.45) = 77.3°. Since ∠ACD equals β/2, and by the inscribed angle theorem, α also equals β/2, we know α = 77.3°!
S12.S12_D14_F83_C2: Great job! Now that we know α, we can ensure that the light will illuminate both the road and walkways.
S12.S12_D15_F84_C1: So, does the illumination angle α always remain the same, or does it change if the tunnel size changes?
S12.S12_D16_F85_C2: Great question! The angle α depends on the tunnel's diameter. If it increases, the spread of light changes as well. Try adjusting the tunnel diameter and observe how α changes.
S12.S12_D17_F86_C1: It's fascinating how α changes as the tunnel diameter increases. This really shows how geometry plays a role in something as practical as lighting design!
S12.S12_D18_F87_C2: Exactly! Now, let's put this to the test. If we increase the tunnel's diameter from 36.9 feet to 44 feet, what is the new light spread angle α?
S12.S12_D19_F88_C1: That's interesting! A larger diameter changes the central angle β, which in turn affects α. This confirms that adjusting the tunnel size directly impacts how light is distributed inside.
S12.S12_D20_F89_C2: Exactly! This is why we carefully calculate every measurement—small changes in geometry can have a big impact on safety and efficiency.

S13.S13_D1_F90_C1: It's incredible to see how every decision, from cable lengths to lighting angles, came down to geometry. I never realized how much math shapes real-world engineering!
S13.S13_D2_F91_C3: And this is more than just math—it's about designing a solution that will save people time and improve transportation across the fjord. This could change how we build tunnels in the future!
S13.S13_D3_F92_C1: It's exciting to think about! We didn't just solve equations—we designed something that could impact thousands of people every day.
S13.S13_D4_F93_C2: That's engineering—turning mathematical principles into real, functional structures. And as we refine the tunnel's design, we'll continue using these same principles to make it safer, stronger, and more efficient.

quest_completion.subheading: Engineering the Depths: The Mathematics of Norway's Floating Tunnel
quest_completion.content:
You completed the Fjord Tunnel Engineering Quest!

  • Explored the geometry of circles and its role in designing a stable floating tunnel
  • Calculated support cable lengths using the Pythagorean theorem to ensure structural stability
  • Determined anchor angles using the Secant-Tangent Theorem to prevent tunnel sway
  • Applied Thales' theorem and trigonometry to find the optimal tunnel diameter for road safety
  • Used the Inscribed Angle Theorem to design efficient lighting for clear visibility

With these mathematical tools in your toolkit, you're ready to design innovative solutions for tomorrow's engineering challenges!

tangent.definition: Tangent is a line that touches a circle at exactly one point without crossing it.

tangents.definition: Tangent is a line that touches a circle at exactly one point without crossing it.

radius.definition: Radius is the distance from the center of a circle to any point on its edge.

diameter.definition: Diameter is twice the radius, representing the total width of the tunnel at its widest point.

inscribed_angle.definition: Inscribed Angle is formed by two chords that meet at a point on a circle.

inscribed_angles.definition: Inscribed Angles are formed by two chords that meet at a point on a circle.

central_angle.definition: Central Angle is an angle whose vertex is at the center of the circle.

secant.definition: Secant is a line that cuts through a circle at two points.

fjord.definition: Fjord is a deep, narrow body of water between steep cliffs, formed by glaciers.

pythagorean_theorem.definition: The Pythagorean Theorem states that in a right triangle, the square of the length of the hypotenuse equals the sum of the squares of the lengths of the other two sides a² + b² = c².

pythagoras_theorem.definition: The Pythagoras theorem states that in a right triangle, the square of the length of the hypotenuse equals the sum of the squares of the lengths of the other two sides a² + b² = c².

chord.definition: A Chord is a straight line segment that connects two points on a circle's circumference.

chords.definition: A Chord is a straight line segment that connects two points on a circle's circumference.

trigonometric_function.definition: Trigonometric function is a mathematical function that relates the angles of a right triangle to the ratios of its sides.

common.hansen_description: An Older man wearing glasses and blue coat over dark sweater.
common.larsen_description: A Man with beard holding tablet wearing dark sweater over shirt.
common.astrid_description: A Woman with curly hair holding tablet wearing dark jacket.
common.bg1_description: Panoramic mountain view of Bjørnafjorden with three figures overlooking the expansive fjord.
common.bg2_description: Norwegian fjord highway with vehicles waiting in line and a cruise ship sailing through the waters.
common.bg3_description: Person holding tablet displaying floating tunnel design with snow-capped mountains and fjord waters.
common.bg4_description: Modern conference room with floor-to-ceiling windows and interactive table displaying tunnel designs.
common.bg5_description: Sleek meeting room with professionals examining tunnel projections against fjord backdrop.
common.bg6_description: Tunnel entrance view showing cylindrical structures extending into the fjord with mountains beyond.

game.circles-engineering-the-depth: STEAM Quest - Circles Engineering the Depth
